What about small towns with little to no cases of COVID? What about cities that have many people working like normal (just from home instead), or make a large number of online sales? I suspect some people/areas will benefit from our COVID chaos while others definitely don't, but either way, the net effect will be what affects all of us for the months (years?) to come. name: Anonymous
comment info: I noticed that many of the rises and falls of major industries during the COVID-19 pandemic have balanced out surprisingly well. Major industries, such as movie theaters and airlines, have taken very heavy hits. While movie theaters have been hit severely by the state guidelines in place, streaming services have grown significantly, along with other digital entertainment services, such as gaming. Airlines, which many people previously spent large quantities of money on for vacations  or for business trips, are now not taking as much of people’s money. This money is likely to have been rerouted elsewhere, such as home improvement or alcohol. While seemingly random, the large amounts of money for travel (to entertaining vacations) have been redirected towards home renovations or other at-home pleasure activities. These are the less obvious changes in expenditures, with the more obvious ones being physical purchasing of items such as apparel and food, being swapped for digital or delivery versions of the same services. This shows the forces of supply and demand in the modern market balancing out, even amidst a global crisis. The after-effects of this pandemic will be very interesting to observe later on, especially whether or not major industries that have been affected stay the way they do, or change back to the way they formerly were.
